nodes.label: Hypothesis

properties.description: The American Revolution was an ideological and political movement culminating in the Revolutionary War.

nodes.label: Hypothesis

properties.description: Taxation without representation violated rights as Englishmen.

nodes.label: Hypothesis

properties.description: Long-standing self-governance created a desire for autonomy, which was violated by post-1763 British policy changes.

nodes.label: Hypothesis

properties.description: Purpose of Townshend Acts was to raise revenue, not regulate trade.

nodes.label: Hypothesis

properties.description: King George's control of Parliament collapsed due to Siege of Yorktown.

nodes.label: Evidence

properties.description: Widespread descriptions of Boston Massacre turning colonial sentiment against British.

nodes.label: Evidence

properties.description: Robert Middlekauff's statement: 'Americans had become almost completely self-governing' before the American Revolution.

nodes.label: Evidence

properties.description: Capt. Levi Preston's quote: '…we always had governed ourselves, and we always meant to. They didn’t mean we should.'

nodes.label: Evidence

properties.description: British government ceased Molasses Act enforcement after 1740s due to smuggling/protest.

nodes.label: Evidence

properties.description: Limits on foreign-built ships greatly benefitting colonial shipbuilding industry.

nodes.label: Evidence

properties.description: Colonists did not object that Stamp Act taxes were high; they were low, but objected to lack of representation.

nodes.label: Evidence

properties.description: John Dickinson's 'Letters from a Farmer in Pennsylvania' arguing against constitutionality of Townshend Acts for revenue.

nodes.label: Evidence

properties.description: Publication of Hutchinson and Oliver letters revealing systematic plot against American rights, discrediting Hutchinson.

nodes.label: Evidence

properties.description: Boycotts of Townshend Acts were less effective due to widespread use of taxed goods.

nodes.label: Causal_Mechanism

properties.description: Escalation of conflict: British policies provoking colonial grievances, leading to protests and organized resistance, escalating to armed conflict and ultimately independence.

nodes.label: Causal_Mechanism

properties.description: Erosion of colonial self-governance leading to resentment: British shift from salutary neglect to direct intervention (taxes, quartering, governance changes) undermined established colonial self-rule, fostering deep resentment and desire for independence.

nodes.label: Causal_Mechanism

properties.description: Mobilization of colonial resistance: Emergence of organized groups (Sons of Liberty) and coordinated networks (Committees of Correspondence) to protest British policies, enforce boycotts, and unify patriot efforts across colonies.

nodes.label: Causal_Mechanism

properties.description: Economic grievance mechanism: British mercantilist policies and new taxes created economic burdens and perceived injustices, motivating merchant opposition and broader colonial protests.

nodes.label: Alternative_Explanation

properties.description: Economic impact of Navigation Acts was minimal on colonists.

nodes.label: Alternative_Explanation

properties.description: Americans only objected to internal taxes and not to external taxes such as custom duties.

edges.label: constrains
